p.s: It is the first time for Starr to get back there where the incident took place.
The whole thing plays out before her eyes.
Starr sees Khalil looking at ther for the last time.
Getting back to this place is difficult for Starr.
This part of the novel is written in the first-person narrative.
This effects that all readers emphasize in Starr's situation ebcause it is only about her feelings and impressions that she remembers from this place.
Starr went back there again for Khalil and because his murder is not guilty.
The crowd shouts A hairbrush is not a gun and the voice snaps Starr from her daze.
She cannot believe that protests are for Khalil and that this really happens.
When Ms. Ofrah spotted Starr in the crowd she changes her state of mind.
She will fight for Khalil and his justice.
When Starr gets on the top of a cop car with Ms. Ofrah's bullhorn in her hands, she seems to be a bit nervous.
But then she starts to say who she is and she was a member of that incident.
This is the changing moment where Starr ends up her divided life.
Her Garden Heights life with her black friends and family in a black poor neighbourhood and her rich and mostly white life at the Williamson Prep School.
Everybody should know what Starr had to see and that she is a tafftough and brave young black girl.
She is going to be an activist for black power movements like Ms. Ofrah.
The little and shy girl has changed to a young and strong woman.
